doc:
Peggy Ann Wood https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peggy_Ann_Wood 0 Peggy Ann Wood (14 June 1912 – 30 May 1998) was a British actress, director and theatre manager associated heavily with the Bristol Old Vic. In partnership with her husband, Ronald Russell (1910–1994), she ran the repertory company the Rapier Players, based in Bristol's Colston Hall. During the Second World War, Peggy Ann Wood ran the theatre whilst Ronnie served in the Police War Reserves, and once the Prince's Theatre had been bombed in November 1940, the Rapier Players provided the only live theatre in the city of Bristol. The contribution of Ronnie Russell and Peggy Ann Wood to the theatrical heritage of Bristol was commemorated with a Blue Plaque Ceremony in July 2002, which is situated on the outside of Colston Hall, Bristol. Peggy_Ann_Wood ( 14_June_1912 – 30_May_1998 ) was a_British_actress_,_director_and_theatre_manager associated heavily with the_Bristol_Old_Vic . In partnership with her_husband , Ronald_Russell_(_1910 – 1994_) , she ran the_repertory_company the_Rapier_Players , based in Bristol 's_Colston_Hall . During the_Second_World_War , Peggy_Ann_Wood ran the_theatre whilst Ronnie served in the_Police_War_Reserves , and once the_Prince 's_Theatre had_been_bombed in November_1940 , the_Rapier_Players provided the_only_live_theatre in the_city of Bristol . The_contribution of Ronnie_Russell and Peggy_Ann_Wood to the_theatrical_heritage of Bristol was_commemorated with a_Blue_Plaque_Ceremony in July_2002 , which is_situated on the_outside of Colston_Hall , Bristol .
